articles.headline: Why Conspiracy Theories Are So Addictive Right Now
articles.snippet: QAnon, #TrumpCovidHoax and other conspiracy theories may be part of a larger authority crisis created by the internet.
articles.abstract: QAnon, #TrumpCovidHoax and other conspiracy theories may be part of a larger authority crisis created by the internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The other night, as President Trump convalesced at Walter Reed, I took a spin through social media to see the latest news on his health.

articles.headline: Anxious for a Lifeline, the U.S. Economy Is Left to Sink or Swim
articles.snippet: President Trump cut off negotiations over a new aid package on Tuesday. Economists of all stripes agree that could be a costly mistake.
articles.abstract: President Trump cut off negotiations over a new aid package on Tuesday. Economists of all stripes agree that could be a costly mistake.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here is the situation the U.S. economy faces, a month before Election Day: Job growth is stalling. Layoffs are mounting. And no more help is coming, at least not right away.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Facebook Widens Ban on Political Ads as Alarm Rises Over Election
articles.snippet: Political ads will be banned indefinitely after polls close on Nov. 3 and the company plans new steps to limit misinformation about the results.
articles.abstract: Political ads will be banned indefinitely after polls close on Nov. 3 and the company plans new steps to limit misinformation about the results.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the past few weeks, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, and his lieutenants have watched the presidential race with an increasing sense of alarm.

articles.headline: Wait, Wall Street Is Pro-Biden Now?
articles.snippet: Investors are warming to the possibility of a “blue wave” as Joseph R. Biden Jr. rises in the polls and the chances of a contested election diminish.
articles.abstract: Investors are warming to the possibility of a “blue wave” as Joseph R. Biden Jr. rises in the polls and the chances of a contested election diminish.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Follow our live Biden vs. Trump 2020 election coverage.]

articles.headline: Trump Calls His Illness ‘a Blessing From God’
articles.snippet: In a video on Wednesday evening, the president portrayed an unproven antibody cocktail being developed by the drug maker Regeneron as a miracle cure.
articles.abstract: In a video on Wednesday evening, the president portrayed an unproven antibody cocktail being developed by the drug maker Regeneron as a miracle cure.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump claimed on Wednesday that catching the coronavirus was “a blessing from God” and portrayed as a miracle cure the unproven therapeutic drug he was given after testing positive last week for the virus.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: Virus Takes Center Stage as Pence and Harris Skirmish in Debate
articles.snippet: Vice President Mike Pence and Senator Kamala Harris met in a face-off that was more civil than the unruly presidential event but featured sharp exchanges over the virus, China policy, job creation and health care.
articles.abstract: Vice President Mike Pence and Senator Kamala Harris met in a face-off that was more civil than the unruly presidential event but featured sharp exchanges over the virus, China policy, job creation and health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Mike Pence and Senator Kamala Harris clashed over the Trump administration’s handling of the coronavirus pandemic on Wednesday night, with Mr. Pence defending the White House’s record without addressing its fundamental failures, while Ms. Harris accused him and President Trump of presiding over a catastrophic failure in public-health policy.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Pence, Peerless Trump Defender, Confronts His Limits
articles.snippet: During an orderly debate, the vice president deflected criticism of the Trump administration’s pandemic response, something Kamala Harris said “clearly” hasn’t worked.
articles.abstract: During an orderly debate, the vice president deflected criticism of the Trump administration’s pandemic response, something Kamala Harris said “clearly” hasn’t worked.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice President Mike Pence approached his task on Wednesday as he has approached his four years as the executive straight man to an unruly leader: not merely defending President Trump but effectively insisting, with poker-faced conviction, that those who doubt his boss should not believe their eyes and ears.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Annie Karni

articles.headline: Pandemic Exposes Holes in Sweden’s Generous Social Welfare State
articles.snippet: Decades of budget-cutting and market reforms laid the ground for a wave of death in Swedish nursing homes.
articles.abstract: Decades of budget-cutting and market reforms laid the ground for a wave of death in Swedish nursing homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the popular imagination, Sweden does not seem like the sort of country prone to accepting the mass death of grandparents to conserve resources in a pandemic.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Erik Augustin Palm

articles.headline: A Columnist Makes Sense of Wall Street Like None Other (See Footnote)
articles.snippet: Finance journalism isn’t known for its writerly voices. Matt Levine, the author of Money Stuff, is an oddball exception.
articles.abstract: Finance journalism isn’t known for its writerly voices. Matt Levine, the author of Money Stuff, is an oddball exception.
articles.lead_paragraph: On April 20, something occurred that was unprecedented in the history of financial markets: The price of oil went negative.

articles.headline: Black LinkedIn Is Thriving. Does LinkedIn Have a Problem With That?
articles.snippet: The social network’s tone has long reflected corporate America: staid, monolithic, white. Now Black users are speaking up — and saying the site is limiting their voice.
articles.abstract: The social network’s tone has long reflected corporate America: staid, monolithic, white. Now Black users are speaking up — and saying the site is limiting their voice.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day in September, Elizabeth Leiba opened the LinkedIn app and saw a post by Aaisha Joseph, a diversity consultant with nearly 16,000 followers on the platform.

articles.headline: While Millions Lost Jobs, Some Executives Made Millions in Company Stock
articles.snippet: Some corporate bosses who received stock awards this year are sitting on gains of millions of dollars.
articles.abstract: Some corporate bosses who received stock awards this year are sitting on gains of millions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as millions of people have lost their jobs during the pandemic, the soaring stock market since the spring has delivered outsize gains to the wealthiest Americans. And few among the superrich have done as well as corporate executives who received stock awards this year.
